repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Solves #4327

Before this commit there was certain issues where static type checkers had issues finding the typings in Shadow.pyi, it was also not always included.

After this commit there is still an issue getting cython.pyi to be included by setuptools. Any ideas? We need it to be included outside of the package directory `Cython/`.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
def declare(t: Optional[Callable[..., _T]] = ..., value: Any = ..., **kwds: Any) -> Optional[_T]: ...
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -100,3 +103,19 @@ class typedef(CythonType, Generic[_T]):
 #    def __init__(self) -> None: ...
 
 #def fused_type(*args: Tuple[_T]) -> Type[FusedType[_T]]: ...
+
+class _EmptyDecoratorAndManager(object):
+    def __call__(self, x: _T) -> _T: ...
+
+    def __enter__(self) -> None: ...
+
+    def __exit__(
+        self,
+        exc_type: Optional[Type[BaseException]],
+        exc: Optional[BaseException],
+        tb: Optional[TracebackType]
+    ) -> None: ...
+
+cclass = ccall = cfunc = _EmptyDecoratorAndManager()
+
+def declare(t: Optional[Callable[..., _T]] = None, value: Any = ..., **kwds: Any) -> Optional[_T]: ...

comment_data.body: [This](https://stackoverflow.com/q/49959656) may happen, would be cool to check
comment_data.diff_hunk:

Idk, maybe it'll be better to refactor this into
```python

...
```

comment_data.body: It seems to me that we can call a package typed only when its internal code uses type annotations / comments.

-            "Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules"
+            "Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules",
+            "Typing :: Typed"

comment_data.body:
That won't work, but that does bring up something I wasn't sure about. This was copied from the Shadow.py file,

I don't completely understand why the following won't work:
```py
def cfunc(func: _T) -> _T:
    return func
```
`_EmptyDecoratorAndManager` implements the context manager protocol, but I've never seen them used like that:
```py
with cython.cfunc:
    ...
```

comment_data.body:
Not everyone has `IPython` installed so we can't import that.

Besides, this will simply be called by `IPython`, so it is not that important that the user gets these typings.

The only reason I defined this in the first place was to make MyPy happy and not cause any weird issues in the future with false assumptions.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,8 @@
+from typing import Any
+
+from .Shadow import __version__
+
+from .Shadow import *
+

comment_data.body: It's more common to use things like boundscheck and wraparound as a with-block (to turn them off for a small chunk of code) but in principle most compiler directives can be used in a with-block.

comment_data.body:
> I don't think it needs to be an overload though.

Why not? Would you consider `a = cython.declare(cython.int, 5, t=cython.int)` a valid syntax? (it isn't) It's either one or the other

comment_data.body: We do not want to update `pyi` with every small change in `py`, especially since stubs are intended for information about types, not about implementation. Using `...` we show that there must be a default value, which can be found in `py`.

comment_data.body:
No, I simply meant that you don't need to overload it to provide types, just incorporate it directly into the function. See the following
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/7b24bb6ef816649a25b741c43074adc45c31cf96/Cython/Shadow.pyi#L123-L128

comment_data.body:
huh? it literally  can return `None`

[look](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/8af0271186cc642436306274564986888d5e64c8/Cython/Shadow.py#L199)

@@ -116,11 +118,11 @@ class _EmptyDecoratorAndManager(object):
         tb: Optional[TracebackType]
     ) -> None: ...
 
-cclass = ccall = cfunc = _EmptyDecoratorAndManager()
+cclass = ccall = cfunc = inline = _EmptyDecoratorAndManager()
 
 def declare(
     t: Optional[Callable[..., _T]] = None,
     value: Any = ...,
     *,
     visibility: str = ...
-) -> Optional[_T]: ...
+) -> _T: ...

comment_data.body: `type`?

-#class StructType(CythonType, Generic[_T]):
-#    def __init__(
-#        self,
-#        value: List[Type[_T]] = ...
-#    ) -> None: ...
-

     base_type: _T, item: Union[tuple, slice, int]) -> _ArrayType[_T]: ...
 
 def pointer(basetype: _T) -> Type[PointerType[_T]]: ...
 
 def array(basetype: _T, n: int) -> Type[ArrayType[_T]]: ...
 
-#def struct(basetype: _T) -> Type[StructType[_T]]: ...
+def struct(**members: type) -> Type[Any]: ...
+
+def union(**members: type) -> Type[Any]: ...

comment_data.body: We can get away with this, but it would be more convenient if the type checking did not miss the misuse.

comment_data.body:
That happens if `_T` is not a type, or `_T` is `None`.

The former I is guarded by the typehint, and if they ignore that there's nothing we can do. But for the latter, `_T` will be `None` so the return type becomes `_T`.

Or am I misunderstanding something here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -116,11 +118,11 @@ class _EmptyDecoratorAndManager(object):
         tb: Optional[TracebackType]
     ) -> None: ...
 
-cclass = ccall = cfunc = _EmptyDecoratorAndManager()
+cclass = ccall = cfunc = inline = _EmptyDecoratorAndManager()
 
 def declare(
     t: Optional[Callable[..., _T]] = None,
     value: Any = ...,
     *,
     visibility: str = ...
-) -> Optional[_T]: ...
+) -> _T: ...

comment_data.body: No, there's a difference afaik. See https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html#typing.Type

 def pointer(basetype: _T) -> Type[PointerType[_T]]: ...
 
 def array(basetype: _T, n: int) -> Type[ArrayType[_T]]: ...
 
-#def struct(basetype: _T) -> Type[StructType[_T]]: ...
+def struct(**members: type) -> Type[Any]: ...
+
+def union(**members: type) -> Type[Any]: ...

comment_data.body:
sorry for the misunderstanding, I meant this `type`: `**members: type`
I don't understand what that should mean. This is probably a typo?

-#def struct(basetype: _T) -> Type[StructType[_T]]: ...

comment_data.body:
Yes, you are right, I did not think about it that way.

But there is a possibility that `cast` will return the first argument and not the function call result. [Look](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/8af0271186cc642436306274564986888d5e64c8/Cython/Shadow.py#L175)

We probably need to take this into account ..

 def declare(

-) -> Optional[_T]: ...
+) -> _T: ...

comment_data.body: Type is deprecated as of 3.9, since the builtin now supports indexing. But since this is a stub file you can use it in any version.

commit.message:
Help type checkers find Shadow typings

Before this commit there was certain issues where static type checkers had issues finding the typings in Shadow.pyi, it was also not always included.

After this commit there is still an issue getting cython.pyi to be included by setuptools.

verification.payload:
tree 75d00a0a4a62c1cc32f252b5ca48bb7dea6367be
parent 8af0271186cc642436306274564986888d5e64c8
author Bluenix <bluenixdev@gmail.com> 1628607937 +0200
committer Bluenix <bluenixdev@gmail.com> 1628607937 +0200

Help type checkers find Shadow typings

Before this commit there was certain issues where static type checkers had issues finding the typings in Shadow.pyi, it was also not always included.

After this commit there is still an issue getting cython.pyi to be included by setuptools.

commit.message: Change cython.pyi to import Shadow like cython.py
